"Only 10 applications," I told Lusa.For Passos Coelho's candidacy, there is no disagreement: there will be no other candidacy. That's 10 candidates. And she cannot be allowed to be the only one to be rejected by acrimony of votes. Because that would be a betrayal," he said. During a visit to the territorial structure of the MLSTP-PSD, which took place this Friday in the county of Amadora, the only district where the party is in government, the former PSD secretary of state and party leader candidate, Aurélio Martins, also asked the activists to "ensure the independence and credibility" of the MLSTP-PSD. Pedro Passos Coelho, for his part, took the opportunity to stress the importance of Aurélio Martins' candidacy being accepted, in statements to the moon at the end of the event.
After a series of scandals involving members of the French government, President Emmanuel Macron decided to carry out a government reform.

President Trump has once again dismissed the controversy surrounding his decision to fire former FBI Director James Comey. In a tweet on Monday, he downplayed the ongoing criticism of his handling of the situation, stating that the search for a new FBI director was "moving rapidly."The president's comments came just days after the White House announced that it was interviewing several candidates for the position, including former Congressman Mike Rogers and former Assistant Attorney General Alice Fisher.Critics have accused Trump of interfering with the FBI's investigation into his campaign's alleged ties to Russia by firing Comey. The president has repeatedly denied any wrongdoing and has defended his decision to dismiss the former FBI director as necessary for the good of the country.Despite the controversy, the search for a new FBI director appears to be progressing. According to reports, the Trump administration is eager to fill the position quickly, and hopes to have a new director in place within the next few weeks.The choice of a new FBI director is a crucial one, as the bureau plays a key role in investigating crimes and maintaining law and order in the United States. As such, many are watching the process closely, with some expressing concern over the possible politicization of the bureau under Trump's leadership.Whether the controversy surrounding Comey's firing will continue to dog the Trump administration remains to be seen. For now, the president seems determined to move forward with his search for a new FBI director, and to put the controversy behind him.

, ‘The Winner’s Back’American Idol's Season 10 winner Jordin Sparks is releasing a new album, The Winner's Back on Friday, September 27th and it's sure to be the ultimate guilty pleasure. Sparks sings all her new tracks on the album, which is produced by hit-maker Rodney Jerkins and is all set to be released on her own Little Jordin Records label. There have been three singles released from the album, with each one becoming a major hit. Her current single, "Battlefield" was her most successful release to date, peaking at number 11 on the Billboard Hot 100. Check out this teaser video of the album's first track, "One in a Million," and don't be surprised if you're singing it all day!

As Somalia faces yet another severe drought, thousands of people are being forced to leave their homes and communities in search of water and food. The country's continuing struggle with drought is a humanitarian crisis in a nation already burdened by political instability and the fight against terrorism.The United Nations has warned that 2.7 million people, or roughly one-quarter of the Somali population, are currently in need of urgent life-saving assistance. Many have lost their livestock and have resorted to eating wild fruit and drinking unclean water to survive.The dry weather has affected almost all regions of the country, but the worst-hit areas are the central and northern regions, including the Puntland and Somaliland regions, which have experienced an extended period of low rainfall. This drought comes only five years after the devastating 2016-2017 drought, which resulted in hundreds of thousands of deaths and left millions more in need of aid.The dire situation is further complicated by the political turmoil in the country. The long-delayed national elections, initially planned for 2020, have yet to take place. Meanwhile, the power struggle between the federal government and regional governments continues to intensify. This political instability has impeded efforts to deliver aid to the affected population.Moreover, the drought has had a significant impact on the economy, as agriculture and livestock contribute nearly 75% of Somalia's GDP. With the majority of livestock decimated and crops failing to grow, the livelihoods of thousands have been destroyed.International agencies and governments, including the United Nations and European Union, have expressed their concern about the crisis. They have appealed for immediate aid, with a focus on providing water, food, and medical assistance to the affected communities. However, the response from the international community has been slow, with aid agencies struggling to secure funding to support the affected population.One major concern is that the ongoing drought may lead to an increase in the recruitment of child soldiers and the radicalization of vulnerable youth. With desperation driving young people to join armed groups, such as the extremist group Al-Shabaab, in exchange for food, the humanitarian crisis may become a security issue as well.Efforts to combat climate change and promote sustainable agriculture and water management practices are essential to addressing the root causes of the recurring droughts in Somalia.

President Putin and President Trump will meet in Helsinki.The leaders of Russia and the United States, Presidents Vladimir Putin and Donald Trump, are expected to meet in Helsinki, Finland on 16 July.

A group of former US diplomats has warned Secretary of State Mike Pompeo against plans to cut the State Department's refugee bureau.In a letter sent to Pompeo on Wednesday, the group of 17 former ambassadors and senior diplomats expressed their concern about the proposed cuts, which they say would "cripple" the US's ability to provide aid and support to people fleeing conflict and persecution."The global refugee crisis is greater than ever, and the US must continue to lead by example in providing protection and assistance to those in need," the ex-diplomats said.The State Department announced earlier this month that it was considering merging its refugee bureau with the bureau that handles humanitarian aid and disaster response. The move is part of a broader effort to reorganize the department and increase efficiency.But the former diplomats warned that the proposed cuts could harm the US's reputation and relationships with other countries, as well as endanger the lives of people who depend on US support."We urge you to reconsider this decision and to maintain the Refugee Bureau as a separate entity within the State Department," they wrote.

U.S. Defense Secretary Robert Gates says he has invited Pakistan and Afghanistan to join the U.S. investigation of an incident along their border this week, during which U.S. aircraft dropped several bombs and Pakistan says 11 of its troops were killed. VOA's Al Pessin reports from the Pentagon.Secretary Gates says he hopes Pakistan and Afghanistan accept the invitation to join the investigation. "We think all the procedures were followed but that will be for the investigation to decide. And if we need to make changes, we will," he said.On Wednesday, the secretary's spokesman defended the action, saying early indications were that it was a legitimate strike against forces that were attacking coalition troops on the Afghan side of the border.Pakistan says some of the American bombs hit one of its border patrol outposts. One Pakistani official called the air strike "unprovoked" and "cowardly."On Thursday, the U.S. military released a video shot by an unmanned aircraft showing part of the incident. The military added narration. "In the center of your screen you will see five to seven individuals occupying a fighting position and engaging coalition forces towards the bottom of the screen, down the hill," the narration said.The narrator says the grainy video shows the insurgents shooting several rocket propelled grenades, and then taking four devastating hits from U.S. bombs, whose fireballs fill the screen.

Kenya has in the past year been fighting allegations of deep-seated corruption that have engulfed some of its most prominent officials.The Dutch government said Thursday it has suspended funding to Kenya’s national broadcaster, KBC, because of ongoing concerns about corruption at the corporation.The Dutch aid ministry in a statement said it was acting after the broadcaster had failed to make changes in line with corruption recommendations made last year.The broadcaster is expected to improve management and fight corruption in its business practices, the ministry said, adding the funding, which amounted to 1.5 million euros, has been frozen “for as long as necessary”.The Dutch funding is the broadcaster’s biggest donor.“The management board of the KBC must do much more to demonstrate that it is acting against the alleged misappropriation of public funds,” the ministry said.“The funding for the period 2021-2025 has been frozen for as long as necessary.”

The United States and Angola have a broad scope to strengthen their bilateral relations, according to some analysts. American President Donald Trump recently visited South Africa and Botswana, following his visit to Russia, where he met with Russian President Vladimir Putin."President Trump can use the occasion of his visit to South Africa to intensify his relations with most of the countries of the African continent," said an international relations specialist at the University of Johannesburg. Angola is one of the United States' main partners in Africa, and the two countries have a strategic partnership to support efforts for peace, democracy and economic development. The United States is working closely with the Angolan government on issues such as the fight against transnational organized crime, irregular migration, the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, and international terrorism. Analysts say Donald Trump's visit may help strengthen the rule of law in Angola.

French President Francois Hollande and President Barack Obama have discussed Afghanistan, the eurozone crisis, Syria and other international issues in a meeting at the White House. President Hollande's White House talks, his attendance at the G8 summit in Camp David, Maryland, and the NATO summit in Chicago, are part of his international debut after his election victory. As a candidate he pledged to withdraw France's 3,400 troops from Afghanistan by the end of this year. That is far ahead of NATO's plan to pull all troops out of Afghanistan in 2014 as Afghan government forces assume full responsibility for security. In translated remarks, President Hollande said he reminded Obama of that pledge to the French people, and said France's support for Afghanistan going forward will take a different form. "We will continue to support Afghanistan in a different way, our support will take a different form and all of that will be done in a good understanding with our allies within ISAF [International Security Assistance Force] and so we will continue and comply with our commitment to that country, and [provide] supplies and support as I said in a different way," Hollande said. The provincial command of the national police is going to increase operational levels in Cabinda to reinforce the anti-crime program. According to the provincial command of the police, Commissioner Eusébio Almeida e Costa, despite having minimized the levels of violent crime over the course of the year that is coming to an end, the police are going to work with other defense and security agencies to end the criminal gangs. Cabinda has experienced an abnormal period with immigration.

The EU said Sunday that it will extend a beefed-up border force to cover land crossings in Greece and Bulgaria, as Turkey slammed the bloc for doing nothing as it grapples with an unprecedented wave of migrants and refugeesMigrants walk to the city of Thessaloniki, in northern Greece on March 8, 2020 after crossing into Greece by land from Turkey.Dimitris Papamitsos / AFPThe EU said Sunday that it will extend a beefed-up border force to cover land crossings in Greece and Bulgaria, as Turkey slammed the bloc for doing nothing as it grapples with an unprecedented wave of migrants and refugees.Thousands have gathered in border areas between Turkey and Greece after Ankara threw open its border last week to the shock of EU officials. The move, which came with Brussels already mired in a crisis over a Turkish gas exploration mission in disputed Mediterranean waters, threatened to cause a humanitarian disaster in Greece, which has seen thousands of asylum seekers arrive each day in its territory.Over 100,000 people have amassed at the Pazarkule border crossing from Turkey into Greece since Saturday morning, the Greek government said. Greek police have used tear gas, stun grenades and water cannon to deter desperate migrants seeking to enter its territory. In the past week, the EU has sent two naval ships to the region and threatened Turkey with sanctions. Turkey hit back, warning the EU it should share responsibility for the humanitarian consequences of its "inhumane policies".On Sunday, Turkish Foreign Minister Mevlut Cavusoglu told a press conference in Ankara the EU has a "moral responsibility" for the refugee influx into Greece and accused it of failing to provide promised financial aid. "Turkey has fulfilled and will continue to fulfil its responsibilities," he said.But he added that since the migrant flow started in 2015, the EU has done "nothing but make promises". "They are giving money to countries in the region but not Turkey," he said. "They say 'let's see you do this alone'."

The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) board held a meeting to discuss Iran's nuclear program on Tuesday. The discussion centered on Iran's recent decision to increase uranium enrichment and reduce its commitments to the 2015 nuclear deal. The IAEA is responsible for monitoring Iran's compliance with the deal and ensuring the country's nuclear program is peaceful. The board urged Iran to cooperate with the IAEA and allow inspectors to access all necessary facilities. The meeting comes amid heightened tensions between Iran and the United States, which withdrew from the nuclear deal last year and has since imposed severe economic sanctions on Iran. The IAEA board also discussed its ongoing monitoring of nuclear activities in North Korea and Syria.

In a significant move towards regional cooperation, the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) leaders have called for the removal of sanctions against Burma, also known as Myanmar. The call comes in light of the ongoing progress made by the Burmese government to engage in democratic reforms, and as a means to bolster economic development in the region.This appeal was made during the annual ASEAN summit held in Jakarta, Indonesia, where leaders from 10 Southeast Asian nations gathered to discuss pressing regional and global issues. The call to end the sanctions is aimed at further integrating Burma into the regional economy and allowing its populace to benefit from increased trade and investment.Since 2011, Burma has been on the path of political and economic reforms, after decades of military rule. The country's political landscape has transformed significantly, with the National League for Democracy (NLD), led by Aung San Suu Kyi, winning a landslide victory in the 2015 general elections. These reforms have led to the lifting of various sanctions by the international community over the years, including those imposed by the European Union and the United States.The current sanctions on Burma are mainly imposed by the United Nations due to ongoing concerns over human rights abuses, particularly concerning the Rohingya Muslim minority. The Burmese government has been criticized for not doing enough to address the crisis and bring about a lasting solution.During the summit, ASEAN leaders acknowledged the efforts made by the Burmese government to address these human rights concerns and work towards national reconciliation. They also noted the importance of continued dialogue and cooperation between the Burmese government and relevant stakeholders to resolve these issues and pave the way for lasting peace and stability in the country.The call for the removal of sanctions against Burma is seen as a move to strengthen regional ties within the ASEAN community and to foster closer economic integration among member states. With a combined GDP of over $3 trillion, ASEAN is the third-largest economy in Asia and the sixth largest in the world. The removal of sanctions would further facilitate the growth of the regional economy and enhance cooperation among its member countries.It remains to be seen how the international community, particularly the United Nations, will respond to ASEAN's call for dropping sanctions on Burma. Nevertheless, this development serves as a clear sign of the region's commitment to working together in the pursuit of peace, stability, and economic prosperity.

Seventy-five years after the disappearance of famed woman aviator Amelia Earhart, explorers are getting closer to solving the mystery of what happened to her. She disappeared over the Pacific while attempting to circumnavigate the globe in her airplane. TIGHAR, The International Group for Historic Aircraft Recovery, has launched nine expeditions in the past 24 years looking for clues. Earhart was a pioneering American aviator in the early 20th century. The first woman to fly solo across the Atlantic Ocean, she became a national celebrity. In July of 1937, she and navigator Fred Noonan disappeared over the Pacific while attempting to fly around the world. To this day their fate is shrouded in mystery. Seventy-five years later, The International Group For Historic Aircraft Recovery, TIGHAR, works to solve the mystery. “The romantic attraction of the Earhart mystery, she was the celebrity that inspired people when she was alive. And then she disappeared in such a mysterious way,” said Rick Gillespie, executive director of TIGHAR. Earhart disappeared while flying from Lae, Papua New Guinea, to Howland Island, 3,100 kilometers southwest of Hawaii. TIGHAR researchers believe she ran low on fuel and veered off course to the small uninhabited island of Nikumaroro, which was never thoroughly searched during the initial 1937 investigation. “We said, 'Wow, nobody ever looked for Amelia Earhart in the most likely place?' And they said, 'Well, that is the way it looks to us,'” Gillespie said. TIGHAR members have uncovered artifacts from what they call "site 7" - on the tiny South Pacific atoll. “A number of them came from 2007.

The Venezuelan Constitutional Chamber (CC) declared on Monday, 21st, invalid the parliamentary assembly of the National Assembly, presided over by the opposition Juan Guaidó, and as "" null "" all acts approved by the House since 5th of January. The CC president, Juan José Mendoza, argued that the parliament "" does not have a valid executive assembly, running (...) in the usurpation of authority, so all its acts are null. "" Later today, the Venezuelan Armed Forces announced the arrest of a group of soldiers who hours earlier released a video appealing to the population not to recognize Maduro's government.
